Fields.DialogueText: Hey! Up there!
What?
I can hear footsteps, so I know you're up there! Grab that wrench, the one on the table, and pass it down to me.
Pass you a wrench?

Fields.MenuText: Sure. The wrench on the table... Here you go.
Get it yourself.
Take a break from your repairs and come up here.

Fields.DialogueText: Took you long enough, but thanks.
What?
I don't know who you think you are, refusing orders from your Belle, but I'm going to find out!
Oh! It's you, Kapitan.
Don't pretend you didn't recognize my voice.
Eh. It's tough to hear clearly while working down there.
Fair enough.
So... apparently you believe there's something that warrants my attention more than repairs to our propulsion.
We're going to pass near Sevastopol, and I thought you might want to take a look.
You overestimate how sentimental I can be... but I am glad you told me. I'll come up soon.
*ALARM*
How about right now?
Hm. I guess some sentimental Morganas also want to visit Sevastopol. Let's go!
@BATTLE
You heard me.
Have the Morganas been shooting blanks recently? Maybe they've been running low on ammunition.
You've got to be kidding me.
Look at my armor! It's like they've hardly been trying!

Fields.MenuText: Do you always have to act so tough?
Well, we certainly can't thank your nimble evasion capabilities for our survival...
You really can take a beating.

Fields.DialogueText: If I flinch, so will the troops. As the ship's First Comrade, I must set the example for strong combat discipline.
Tsk tsk. Perhaps, Kapitan, you should have helped with the engine repairs, da?
My iron will is my true armor, Kapitan.
I rather enjoy besting the Neizvestniy flot. Defeating Morganas is even more fun when I imagine they are crewed by Romanians.
Just remember that, when it comes to Morganas, we all play for the same team.
Teamwork, da, da. That I also respect.
Let's keep doing our part, shall we? I need us ready to bring aboard marines for a troop transport mission. They've been tasked with destroying a dam built by Morganas.
I am fully ready, Kapitan.
Are you sure?
Perhaps you are used to working with young, inexperienced Belles... but maybe you will learn in time. When I say I am ready, I am ready.
Thanks for clarifying, Profintern. When I told you I wanted your input this is almost exactly what I meant. Almost exactly!
Don't mention it.
@BATTLE
The marines are aboard, Kapitan.
Fast and efficient. Nice work, Profintern.
Of course.
In fact, it was almost too fast. How did you load all of the extra food so quickly?
Loading extra food was unnecessary. Our galley will support the soldiers' needs.
How are we going to feed all of them?
We won't have to feed them for very long. You will see.

Fields.MenuText: So... after we drop them off for the mission, somebody else takes care of them.
We have to take care of those troops. We should get more provisions.
What do you mean, "for very long?"

Fields.DialogueText: Er, no... Not exactly.
Didn't you hear what I said? It is not going to be a problem.
Is this your first war? I thought it was obvious.
Once the mission begins, most of the marines will die.
We will only have a few wounded and survivors to feed after the battle begins.
Profintern.
Don't hold me responsible. Blame the Morganas. They are the ones who will kill those troops. You've seen the same reports I have.
I appreciate your positivity. Now stay put while I get that food loaded.
@BATTLE
Ah. There may be a problem with that. Look to the south.
They will be storming Morgana fortifications on a dead island, Kapitan. An SVT-38 is only so useful when you have nothing human to shoot.
This is something I never expected to see...
I thought it might be a good idea to help make food for the troops today.
Curious. Are you adopting the ways of the proletariat now?
Maybe I'm just trying to take care of those in my charge.
And thus you truly understand your place. Leader and servant.

Fields.MenuText: Quit romanticizing it. I'm just pitching in to let the crew and troops know that I care.
Feel free to help out.
Where should I get my hammer and sickle tattoo? On my arm, or maybe a big one on my back?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be coy, Kapitan. I'm glad your heart understands, even if your head does not want to admit it.
I have been. I am quite popular with the mechanics for helping out in the engine room.
Hmph. I don't enjoy being mocked, Kapitan.
Let's just try to keep morale up, for their sake.
Da. Of course.
@BATTLE
On that note, how're you doing with Sullivan? And Tate? Is everyone behaving themselves?
Tate is a grandstanding fool.
Really?
... Nyet. He's just not as clever as he thinks he is. But at least now he's competing with me instead of just ignoring me.
Still doesn't sound ideal.
"Ideal" is for children and philosophers, Kapitan. We can work together. It's enough.
Fair enough.
How utterly disappointing, Kapitan.
Always a promising start to a conversation.
Here I am, stopping by your cabin, and I see that you are taking your meals in here.
I had so much hope after seeing you help out in the galley, but you still sequester yourself and eat in here.
Why do you isolate yourself this way? Do you truly believe you are superior to the others?

Fields.MenuText: Somebody has to be the captain, in case you forgot.
I think you're missing the point.
If anything can ruin a meal, it's politics. Thanks for that.

Fields.DialogueText: *sigh*
Then educate me, wise leader.
You're avoiding the question.
All things in moderation, then.
Even if they all smile and say they enjoy my company, some would just be doing their best to be polite and respectful.
I'm sure there are a number of crew members who would prefer that I leave them alone when they are relaxing. Eating my meals alone lets them avoid me.
I understand your decision, although I don't like it. Hierarchies cause more problems than they solve.
Noted. Back to why you visited in the first place, though - did you have something you needed to discuss?
Da. We are not far from the drop off area. If you want to talk to any of those marines before they...
Depart?
Right. Depart. You have a few more hours.
Thanks.
Mighty Kapitan, now would you like me to scrub your dirty dishes?
Dismissed, Profintern.
Ugh...
@BATTLE
You did ask for candor.
True. What have I done now?

Fields.MenuText: A common naval tradition.
I'm eating while I work. You'll note the papers strewn around.

Fields.DialogueText: A captain often eats separately from the crew, and even from the other officers.

Fields.MenuText: ... Really?
I have to maintain some distance from the crew and troops. Being too familiar undermines my ability to lead.
Sometimes I need privacy in order to function.

Fields.DialogueText: You know the hours I work. I'm working now. And there are things I just can't do in the middle of a crowd.
I don't think it's unreasonable to grab the occasional moment when I wouldn't be missed and just... get things done.
I understand. But it's a missed opportunity - the crew values seeing you share in their free time as well as in their labors. It keeps you from seeming elitist.
Our guns are ready to soften up the defenses, Kapitan. I will do you the courtesy of waiting for your order to commence.
As long as I'm being candid, I question whether our friends in command did their homework before giving us this mission. In fact, one might go so far as to say-
Let's not cross the line between sentiment and mutiny, all right?

Fields.MenuText: You're right. "Ours not to wonder why..."
Any good officer thinks about their orders instead of blindly executing.
Stop. You've been pessimistic about this from the start.

Fields.DialogueText: Are you quoting Tennyson? He was on the wrong side of the Crimean War, if you ask me. Still, you have the right idea.
Hesitation is a luxury these troops do not get to enjoy.
I've been realistic, Kapitan. We've done everything we can do, but the marines have a hard fight ahead of them. It will be bloody.
I have my concerns about deploying ground troops against a Morgana infestation without sufficient air support. If there's any way we could give them more of an edge....
I understand.
I respect your concern for our brave fighters, but once they leave our ship, they have their own job to do. Do not take that away from them.
Which is your way of saying there's nothing else we can do. You're right, but... damn.
*ALARM*
And these witches of the Neizvestniy flot arrive to play their part - getting shot full of holes!
Who are we to deny them?
I'm glad we can agree on that...
@BATTLE
... You still look like you're being forced to eat rancid meat.
*ALARM*
We're almost in position, Kapitan. There's just a bit of a barricade to run.
I can't say I'm surprised.
@BATTLE
The beach is in range, Kapitan. Let's keep shelling the defenses.
Fire at will. Give the marines a fighting chance.
With pleasure.
*BOOM*
And they're off.
We're sitting ducks until the troops have all deployed, so keep a sharp eye on the horizon for enemy reinforcements.
*BOOM*
We've been harassed by Morganas continuously on this mission. It's only a matter of time before more of them show up.
*BOOM*
I hate to be a pessimist, but you're right. When they show up...

Fields.MenuText: ... keep all guns focused on the shore bombardment. I want our troops to have cover.
... switch all guns to deal with incoming Morganas. If they take us out, the troops don't have a chance.
... be ready to run.

Fields.DialogueText: Are you sure that's a good idea? We can't help them if the Morganas sink us first.
I agree. Troops paddling ashore would have no defense against the Neizvestniy flot hags.
That is the last thing I would ever choose!
Just keep watching the horizon. I won't relax until all of the troops are away.
*GUNFIRE*
They will proceed as quickly as they can, Kapitan. They know the dangers, too.
The last of the marines have made landfall, Kapitan.
It's up to them now.
*GUNFIRE*
Cease fire, Profintern.
You don't need to tell me that! I'm not one to waste ammunition.

Fields.MenuText: I said cease fire on the beach, Profintern.
Take a breath. I wasn't trying to upset you.
You really hate taking orders, huh?

Fields.DialogueText: Do you still hear the guns? They have stopped, so you can stop running your mouth.
What difference does that make?
Perhaps I do!
I am perfectly capable of accomplishing what needs to be done.
You seem perfectly capable of forgetting who's in charge.
Oh... Trust me when I say that I could never forget that.
Take it easy on the politics for now. Let's just support our crew and those soldiers the best we can, all right?
Fine...
... but be warned.
I have not painted in a few days, and once we get out of this, I cannot guarantee restraint in whatever art I create!
I'll take that under advisement. Thanks for the, uh, warning.
Let's move the ship away from the beach in case we have to deal with visitors.
@BATTLE
Profintern! Climb down! You've been up there for hours!
I can't hear you! Climb up if you want to talk to me!
But you're sitting atop the highest mast!
What? Say that again, I can't hear you!
Come down so we don't have to keep shouting!
Climb up! I can't hear you from all the way up here!
I said climb down!
I can't hear you! Did you say you were too cowardly to climb up?

Fields.MenuText: Climb down!
Fine! I'll climb up!
*sigh* Why can't I get a Belle who isn't insane?

Fields.DialogueText: I can't hear you! Let me climb down first!
I can't hear you! Stay right there while I climb down!
I HEARD THAT!
What do you want, Kapitan?
We have plenty of work to do on board the ship. I want to know why you're sitting on top of a mast for hours instead.
I needed some... perspective.
I hope you got it. But you're on duty and needed on the bridge, so I'd recommend you get moving.
To be lectured by somebody like you on matters of work and labor is so...
Wait until the Morganas are gone before you finish that thought, please.
Hmph!
@BATTLE
I'm climbing down!
*ALARM*
Take that! And THAT!
Profintern? Are you down here in the ammunition storage?
Why, yes! It's a wonderful location because it's so private. I could work here without being interrupted by, say, my kapitan...
Your sarcasm needs work.
Fine, fine. I needed some room to work on my painting.
You mentioned you might be picking up your brushes again soon.

Fields.MenuText: Good for you!
Can I see it?
Don't stay down here too long. Lots of work to do on a ship, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: Spasibo, Kapitan.
It is not finished. Peeking would be unwise.
Your words are ironic and unnecessary.
I promise you will see it when the piece is finished.
Good.
I'm looking forward to it. Those sketches you've left lying around have been exceptionally good.
Oh...
Well...
Now you look like somebody walked over your grave. Are you all right?
Yes... yes, fine. I just need my privacy again for a little while, Kapitan.
...After the battle. I promise.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Look at that! Quite a bold painting, don't you think?
Maybe a little too bold.
Huh? What do you mean?
Look, near the bottom. I don't know what will happen when the Captain sees that.
Huh?
The face. Doesn't it look a lot like...
Whoa! I see it now. Looks like Profintern couldn't help herself.
Esposito. Sullivan. Is that Profintern's new painting?
Um... whoa, is that the time?
Bye!
Why were they so spooked?
Stark red and black patterns, geometric designs...
A heroic female standing proudly and holding a huge hammer...
That she just used to knock out her unconscious enemy...
And her enemy looks an awful lot like...
My dear kapitan!
Like my new painting?

Fields.MenuText: Mutiny isn't a joke, Profintern. Take this down.
A picture of you smashing me with a mallet isn't art. It's more like... a cartoon.
Lovely work, Profintern. I think you really captured my good looks.

Fields.DialogueText: You can't suppress free expression forever, Kapitan! I will take this down, but under protest.
My art?! A cartoon? I... I... I knew you couldn't appreciate it! I'm taking it down!
I doubt somebody like you could ever appreciate true art. I'm taking this down!
Fine with me. Report to the bridge when you're done.
Hmph!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
All engines ahead at flank speed! Get us to the rendezvous point as fast as possible!
What are you doing, Profintern?
What needs to be done, Kapitan.
It is time to recover the marines. Surely you don't object to executing our mission?

Fields.MenuText: Of course not.
Captains typically enjoy knowing what their ship is doing.
I should be the one giving that order.

Fields.DialogueText: Good!
Don't expect me to typically enjoy explaining everything to you.
There was no time to waste.
I just received the message from Command that we needed to get to the rendezvous point right away. I was going to tell you.
One of these days we're going to get along...
Anything else from Command that I should know before I read the report for myself?
Da. Casualties for the troops are as expected. Severe.
@BATTLE
The troops from the mission took heavy losses. We have to get the wounded survivors aboard quickly if we're going to save any of them.
I assure you, Kapitan, I am doing everything in my power to get them aboard.
Let's try to coordinate this better. The fishing boats in the area are causing a traffic jam.
Get out of my way! Soviet cruiser coming through!
This recovery effort is not working...
Move your little boats out of my way or I will ram you out of the way!

Fields.MenuText: I'm trusting you to sort this out, Profintern.
Calm down. This is far too chaotic.
Ramming boats is while on a rescue mission is... the opposite of rescue!

Fields.DialogueText: Let me handle it, and I will.
I make order from chaos, Kapitan. Allow me to handle this.
They'll learn to get out of my way soon enough.
I can take it from here. Perhaps you can talk to Command and inform them of our progress.
I can't believe I'm saying this, but... that's not a terrible idea.
Don't endanger any of these marines. I want to save as many wounded as we possibly can.
We have to be fast, or else the Neizvestniy flot will pounce on us here. Morganas will be drawn to this carnage like sharks.
@BATTLE
So that on the horizon, is that just fins?
*KNOCK*
Come in. You're late, by the way.
So! You have invited me once again to the private residence of the hierarchy itself.
My cabin? Yes.
Da, the luxurious chamber of power...
Really? Luxurious?
Fine. Perhaps not exactly luxurious.
Which... is intentional, of course, because I will not be First Comrade on a ship that would indulge itself in such capitalist gestures.

Fields.MenuText: Then, goodness, I'm glad everything is just how you like it.
So you're shabby... on purpose.
I hope you brought coffee. Political theory makes me sleepy.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmph.
Stop putting words in my mouth.
Hardly surprising, Kapitan.
And so you summon me because... your typewriter needs repairs again?
No. I wanted to talk about the wounded that we evacuated from the beach.
Our ship's doctors stabilized a good number of them.
How many made it?
Eight.
Just eight?
Hauling them aboard quickly tended to open or aggravate their wounds. Many bled out while waiting for medical attention.
Damn. This is exactly what I feared.
What is?
Your-
*ALARM*
Damn! It will have to wait. Set general quarters and get our guns up immediately.
Hurry up, you say. Wait, you say. *sigh*
@BATTLE
Make your report, Lieutenant Esposito.
Spotted some fast-moving shapes on the radar, Captain. I thought it might be a possible Morgana movement in the distance.
Neizvestniy flot scum!
All engines ahead flank and get the crew to battle stations. Our work is cut out for us.
Um...
You heard me, Esposito. Just because our kapitan is standing here doesn't mean you can't take action. Get going!

Fields.MenuText: Belay that order.
Go ahead. The insubordination is a topic for another time.

Fields.DialogueText: Cowardice in the face of the enemy is unbecoming of a warship, Kapitan.
That's what I thought.
Well?!
Visual confirmation. Multiple Morganas heading east across the Black Sea.
Very well, Esposito. Move in to intercept and engage the targets.
Aye-aye, Captain.
Am I invisible? HELLO?!
You're not invisible, but you're not being very productive either.
... Da, I'll be in the engine room cleaning oil filters. If anybody needs me, that's where I'll be.
Don't worry about that right now, Esposito. I'll take care of her later.
Of course, Captain.
@BATTLE
She evades all defenders as she drives with purpose to her objective...
Profintern? We didn't finish our talk.
She dodges to the left and prepares to fire...
Are you listening to me?
She shoots...
I need your attention.
*SMACK*
Oh, for the love of...!
GOAL!

Fields.MenuText: You just hit me in the face with a soccer ball!
Assaulting your superior officer is a crime, you know.
This is not the time for games.

Fields.DialogueText: It was an accident.
It was just a ball. You should be...
Just a bit of exercise.
I'm... sorry about that.
I need your help.
All right.
Command is asking questions about the casualty rate on that assault. Nobody on their side saw how bad it was going to be, and they're trying to figure out what went wrong.
I don't like the sound of that.
*ALARM*
Or that!
@BATTLE
So I want an expanded report - the most thorough write-up we can manage. We want them fixing problems, not just spreading blame around.
Let me see if I understand this correctly.
All right.
Command says that even though the assault on the Morgana... "enigma structure" was technically a success, losses were too high.
That's what I understood from their message to all of the participating units.
Including us.
That's right.
And because so many marines were lost in the attack, they do not have enough people to commence additional missions.

Fields.MenuText: Don't take it personally. We did our part as well as anyone possibly could.
The loss of life was atrocious. Command's right to hold an inquiry.
Maybe we could have coordinated the attack better. If we'd worked faster, fewer men would have--

Fields.DialogueText: I agree with you.
But who is to blame for the failure?
We're not responsible!
Everybody did their part, including us.
But even that isn't always good enough.
If I were in charge, we would have had far fewer losses.
I don't think Command is ready to put a Belle in charge of a major invasion.
That's the problem! Nobody EVER listens to me!
Big generals and admirals make their ridiculous plans and blame the lowly soldiers when it doesn't work.
I'm so tired of it! I'm tired of those pompous fools who don't remember or care what it's like to actually fight!
Hey, Profintern...
WHAT?
I'm on your side, you know. In fact, you might say we're in the same...
Oh, please. Don't say it...
Boat.
That's so... haha! That's so stupid, Kapitan.
Get some rest. I'll work on our report to Command, all right?
Thanks. I... I think I'll do that. Excuse me.
*ALARM*
Battle stations, everyone!
@BATTLE
*sigh*
Hey, do you have a minute?
I'm working on a painting.
Am I going to be in this painting?
Ha! I don't think so. Not this time.
It's just a geometric pattern.
I like the stripes that run across the middle. Very... avant-garde.
Well, that's the idea.
You said some interesting things about the people at Command. About generals and admirals...
How did that report turn out, by the way?
Fine, thanks. I just sent them the details about where and when we provided gunfire support, where and when we deployed the marines.
Just like that?
Just like that. What's on your mind?
Some of the crew thinks I bark about political theory and revolution because I just like to stir up trouble all day long, but it's not true.
Those ideas are actually important to me. I believe in them. They could make the world better if people would listen.

Fields.MenuText: I hope they don't. Communism is a terrible idea.
Making people listen is one of the hardest things in the world. Making them understand is even harder.
People are entitled to their opinions.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, make sure you understand it before you condemn it.
You make it look easy sometimes, Kapitan.
These aren't opinions. They're facts.
I think you, like everybody else, just want to be heard and understood.
There's a lot more to it than just that, but I admit that part is true.
Da. Well. Thanks for talking with me a bit, Kapitan. If you don't mind, I think I'll put some finishing touches on this painting before I come up to the bridge.
They'd better be quick touches. See you there!
@BATTLE
That's fair.
Don't make me blush, First Comrade!
In that case, I'll let you be.
... But I wouldn't mind company.
*ALARM*
Kapitan... one more thing.
Yes?
I know you've spoken with the political officer. On my behalf, I mean. He's much more... respectful than he used to be.
I think you'll find it's making me more efficient overall. So it's a good thing you've done. Thoughtful.
You're welcome. I'm still hoping we can get an American rabbi onboard, too. For efficiency.
That could cause more trouble than it's worth, Kapitan.
Moscow signed off on chaplains on Neutrality Fleet assignments, however grudgingly. You're entitled.
And you've received one too many head wounds if you think they'd smile at someone like me taking advantage.
Depressingly fair point.
How are you doing?
I'm not a child, Kapitan.
I didn't think I was treating you like one.
Did you know that my keel was laid in 1913? In a way, I'm older than most of the crew.
It's knowledge I have, but I don't typically think of your age in that way.
Well, it might help if you did, sometimes.

Fields.MenuText: It might help if you thought of me as your captain - not some kid on the crew.
It might help if you quit fighting with everybody.
I thought Communists were supposed to believe in cooperation.

Fields.DialogueText: I know you are the kapitan. I did not mean to disrespect you.
It might help if people would quit being so stupid.
Is that supposed to be a joke?
Hear me out. I know you're passionate about certain things, but we also have to get along. Getting carried away, getting adversarial... it's counterproductive for us.
A warship can't operate without respect for authority and without cooperation.
I'll try to get along better, Kapitan, but listen to the experience I can provide you.
And also, let people work hard. In fact, demand that they do.
Work with me on the bridge, and we'll make an unstoppable team.
*ALARM*
Time to prove it!
She is quite the runner...
@BATTLE
Basically, as a starting point, I'm asking you to trust that when I ask how you're doing, it's not meant as an attack. I'm not implying you're incapable.
No, but you're expecting me to say something meaningless about being fine. You're not asking me anything real.
*sigh*
Roger, Command. Understand that situation is urgent.
Will respond with haste. We will make best possible speed for those coordinates.
Profintern out.
Lieutenant Esposito!
Yes, Captain.
One of our task forces is under heavy Morgana attack. We have top priority tasking from Command to assist in driving them off.
*gulp*
Do it. The longer it takes us to get there, the more people will die.
Um...
Sullivan, you look pale. Is something wrong?
Esposito, did you tell the Captain yet?
I was about to...

Fields.MenuText: Do you need a slap on the back of the head to help you spit it out?
Tell me.
We don't have time for hesitation! Out with it!

Fields.DialogueText: No, Captain!
Well...
There's a problem...
Profintern sent me up here to report that the engines will be down for an hour or two. We don't have any propulsion.
What in the hell is she doing back there?
Kapitan. Look to the south.
I see them. Action stations!
@BATTLE
Profintern! What in the hell are you doing back here?
Kapitan! I am trying to fix the problem.
And you started by kicking out Sullivan and the engineers? Dammit, Profintern-
I said I'm trying to fix it!

Fields.MenuText: I thought we finally had an understanding, Profintern.
Why did you take the engines down without my permission?
I've had enough of your insubordination.

Fields.DialogueText: We do! I assure you, Kapitan.
I didn't. Please let me explain.
I can explain this.
I did not take the engines offline.
You remember Tate, our star mechanic? Clever boy. He discovered a problem with one of our turbines.
I never heard about it.
Tate tried to take care of it all by himself without telling anyone. Unfortunately, he accidentally shut down all of our turbines.
Right.
Thank you, Kapitan, but I know I've given you plenty of cause.
Also, I'm sorry for setting a bad example for Tate. If I had more self-control, maybe he wouldn't have tried to imitate my....
Anyway, what matters is getting our propulsion back. We have friendlies in need of immediate relief.
It will take some time. I'll help the mechanics restore the engines as fast as we can.
Let me know as soon as we're ready to go.
*ALARM*
Not now!
@BATTLE
And the risk of explosion was high enough that I didn't want the crew too close. I can survive more than they can.
... I think it's safe for you to be here now, though. Probably.
I'd like to apologize, formally, for the shouting.
That's not on you.
Get to the bridge! I'll make sure we're not dead in the water as long as this lasts!
Kapitan!
You have grease in your hair. I hope that's a good sign.
Da. All turbines are restored.
In fact, they might even work a little bit better than before.
Good work, First Comrade.
All engines ahead, flank speed!
What do you plan to do with Tate?

Fields.MenuText: There'll be an investigation. If it's found that he was negligent - or worse - he'll get more than a rap on his knuckles.
I haven't decided yet. Any thoughts?
We have more important things to worry about right now.

Fields.DialogueText: If I might offer a word of advice...
Could I make a recommendation?
Of course, but if I could make a suggestion...
Tate acted with good intentions, and he followed my example. My bad example.
He is contrite, and he really is quite clever. I would ask you to be lenient with him.
I appreciate that. I'll take it into consideration.
For now we have to pull out all the stops. The task force needs our help, and we can expect heavy Morgana resistance along the way.
I will make sure our guns are ready, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
The man's had two potentially catastrophic blunders so far.
Yeah, I still don't-
Moreover, he's part of a team, and his errors really belong to all of us.
If you keep making that face, I have it on good authority that it's going to stick.
Sorry, Captain, but I've been listening to the task force. They're taking some bad hits.
How bad?
It sounds like the Morganas came out from behind a storm front and took the task force by surprise. Damage and casualties are severe.
I know it sounds bad, but we'll be there soon.
That's what I'm afraid of, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: You're a seasoned officer. Act like one.
The task force will still be there. We won't be fighting all of those Morganas alone.
Set a good example for the others. Be brave and lead your team.

Fields.DialogueText: Aye-aye, Captain.
Then the sooner we get there, the better.
I'll do my best, Captain.
Steady as she goes, Esposito.
Lookouts have spotted columns of smoke on the horizon.
Call down to the engine room. Tell Profintern to report to the bridge.
It's time.
@BATTLE
That's all I can ask for.
Two more ships from the friendly task force are trying to withdraw.
The two cruisers over there? The ones that are on fire?
So much black smoke...
They can't stay in the fight. They'll need cover if they're going to get those fires under control.
It might be too late for them.

Fields.MenuText: All guns on the first Morgana pursuing those two cruisers. Let's draw their attention away.
Get us between the Morgana line and those cruisers. Let's block their guns.
... You're right, those two cruisers are probably done for. Let's focus on helping the other ships in the task force.

Fields.DialogueText: A good idea, although it may not be enough to distract them.
I don't know how long my armor will last if we do that, but I'll give it my all.
Don't give up yet, Kapitan, I recommend trying to help. I think they might still have a chance.
I'll signal those two cruisers so they know our intentions.
Good thinking, Profintern.
They may not be able to hear us or respond, but it's worth a shot.
This fight is...
It's going to be ugly. I know.
... Let's go.
@BATTLE
Very well.
Another summons to the cabin of the nautical aristocrat! Da! Oh great monarch of the seas, your lowly serf reports as ordered.
Come on, Profintern. Cut it out.
Da, da. I couldn't help myself that time. It's just our little joke, that's all.
Are you ready? They're waiting for us in the galley.
I'm sure the crew will be glad to see their kapitan helping out in the galley again. It's been some time since you last cooked for them.
I want to show my appreciation. They've been downright heroic.
Such magnanimous praise! Spoken like a true aristocrat!
Ha! I said cut it out!
Haha! In all seriousness, Kapitan, I wanted to show you my appreciation, too. Here.
What's this? A new painting?
Just a small one. It shows two mighty warriors standing atop defeated Morganas.
These colors and shapes are striking. Oh, and these two faces look awfully familiar...
Hm...
Probably just a coincidence. Come on. The crew is getting hungry.
Wait, just a moment. You're trying to tell me something, aren't you?
I'd hoped the picture would get the idea across...
You are my kapitan. But now, I also consider you my friend.
I feel the same way about you, Profintern.
Let's get going to the galley.
After you, First Comrade.
